title: 108_s2589
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. CLARIFICATION OF STATUS OF CERTAIN ORGANIZATIONS AND RETIREMENT PLANS." is about clarifying the status of specific organizations and retirement plans. The text chunk clarifies the status of organizations and retirement plans under specific provisions of the law. It defines how certain organizations maintaining retirement plans are treated for tax purposes and categorizes them as church plans. The text chunk discusses the treatment of retirement plans under specific tax provisions, categorizing them as church plans and specifying how accounts are treated for tax purposes. Money purchase pension plan for retirement plans subject to section 401(a) of the tax code and treated as church plans. The plan is treated as a defined contribution plan and must make an election under section 410(d) for plan years after December 31, 2005. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows retirement plans to commingle assets for investment purposes with other assets of the organization maintaining the plan. This does not subject the other assets to any provisions of the Act. The plan may also operate without being subject to certain sections of the tax code or the Act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows retirement plans to offer a lump-sum distribution option to participants under age 55 without an annuity option. Any account in the plan is treated as a retirement income account for tax purposes. An eligible organization is defined as one where employment by a recognized church qualifies as ministry service. The organization must meet specific criteria to be considered eligible, including being recognized by a church association, being part of an ecumenical movement, providing support to the armed forces, and having a retirement plan administered by a designated organization. The eligible organization must meet certain criteria, including being recognized by a church association, part of an ecumenical movement, supporting the armed forces, and having a retirement plan administered by a designated organization. It must also be established by State law, exempt from tax under section 501(m) of the Internal Revenue Code, and amend its organizing documents by January 1, 2006. The provisions of this section require that a certain percentage of trustees be associated with a church, including past or present service as an officer or board member. These provisions apply to plan years beginning after December 31, 2003. Passed the Senate on July 14, 2004, S. 2589 is an act to clarify the status of certain retirement plans and the organizations maintaining them.
